abstracts.cdata!:
The Health Sector Support Project of
            Chad had the following ratings: outcomes were
            unsatisfactory, risk to development outcome was substantial,
            Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and borrower
            performance was moderately unsatisfactory. The lessons
            learned included: 1) The support of the central ministries
            is essential for an operation with the ambition of
            addressing the most pressing issues in a sector; 2)
            Supervision of a broad-based sector operation should include
            a review of budget implementation for the sector and
            agreement on an updated Medium-Term Expenditure Framework
            (MTEF) on an annual basis. This was not done for the project
            under review; 3) Heroic efforts to get things done at the
            micro level do not bring about expected results if the
            macroeconomic and governance environment becomes
            increasingly hostile. At the mid-term review, which took
            place a month after the portfolio review, the Bank team
            should have come to the conclusion that continued support to
            the sector was difficult to justify under the unchanging
            country circumstances; and 4) In such a challenging and
            difficult country environment fraught with
            governance-related issues, the design of projects should be
            simple and well-targeted.

abstracts.cdata!:
The extension of basic quality health
            services is the main objective of the Health Sector Support
            Project in Chad, to be achieved through the National Health
            Policy, as defined by the Ministry of Public Health (MOPH).
            To this end, the components will: 1) support the development
            of human resources in the areas of health care provision -
            particularly paramedicals - and management, through the
            provision of training, strengthening teaching capacity, and
            monitoring internships; 2) support district health services
            in under-served areas, through the consolidation of health
            services activities, with those under the Social Development
            Action, and the Health and Safe Motherhood Projects,
            allowing expansion of health services, and accessibility to
            health care. This will reinforce delivery of minimum, and
            complementary activities, supporting management, and
            supervisory capacities, and render those currently
            under-served health districts, operational; 3) Strengthen
            health financing, and management in support of the
            decentralization process. The central level capacity will be
            reinforced, to design sector reforms, translated into
            project-targeted areas. Community participation will be
            developed to achieve cost-recovery, and initiate innovative
            practices; 4) build the institutional capacity of MOPH,
            specifically, to support the pharmaceutical, and health
            communications policies. The AIDS control strategy will be
            strengthened, by supporting mobilization of civil society,
            and improving the epidemiological surveillance system, to
            limit HIV transmission risks; and, 5) assist the government
            in collecting socio-demographic data to improve, and monitor
            progress in the health, and population sectors. A health,
            nutrition, and population survey will be conducted by 2002,
            envisaged to contribute to the 2003 census.
